children.name: Strategy, Management, and Systems
children.description: Focuses on formulating and executing business strategies, managing risks, and ensuring sustainability.

children.name: Business Strategy Formulation and Execution
children.description: The process of developing a clear business strategy to achieve organizational goals.

children.name: Risk Management
children.description: Identifying, assessing, and prioritizing risks followed by coordinated efforts to minimize, monitor, and control the probability or impact of unfortunate events.

children.name: Portfolio Management
children.description: Managing an organization's projects and programs in a way that aligns with strategic objectives.

children.name: Sustainability
children.description: Integrating sustainable practices into business strategies to ensure long-term viability.

children.name: Product Management
children.description: Overseeing the development and lifecycle of products from conception to market.

children.description: Creating and communicating a clear vision for the product that aligns with business goals.

children.name: Product Development Team Leader
children.description: Leading teams in the development and delivery of products, ensuring alignment with business strategies.

children.description: Ensuring that business goals, user experience, and technological capabilities are aligned.

children.name: Product Family Management
children.description: Managing a group of related products to maximize market impact and profitability.

children.name: Stakeholder Management
children.description: Identifying and engaging stakeholders to ensure their needs are met throughout the product lifecycle.

children.name: Change Management
children.description: Managing organizational change to minimize resistance and maximize engagement.

children.name: Organizational Structure
children.description: Defining the structure of the organization to facilitate effective communication and workflow.

children.name: Organizational Culture and Climate
children.description: Understanding and influencing the shared values and behaviors of the organization.

children.name: Various Systems
children.description: Implementing systems that support business objectives and facilitate change.

children.name: Human Resources

children.name: Business Processes

children.name: Stakeholder Management (Change)
children.description: Managing stakeholder expectations and engagement during times of change.

children.name: Systems Engineering
children.description: Applying systems engineering principles to ensure successful system development.

children.name: Systems
children.description: Understanding and managing complex systems to achieve strategic goals.

children.name: Lifecycle
children.description: Managing the lifecycle of a system from conception through disposal.

children.name: Processes
children.description: Defining and refining processes within the systems engineering framework.

children.name: Specific Activities in System Lifecycle Processes
children.description: Executing specific activities such as requirements analysis, integration, and testing.

children.name: Requirements Analysis
children.description: Determining and documenting what the system must do to meet business needs.

children.name: Architecting
children.description: Designing the structure of the system to meet specified requirements.

children.name: Implementation
children.description: Building the system components according to the design specifications.

children.name: Integration
children.description: Combining system components to work together as a coherent system.

children.name: Testing
children.description: Verifying that the system meets the requirements through various testing methodologies.

children.name: Operation
children.description: Managing the system's operation to ensure it meets performance standards.

children.name: Maintenance
children.description: Performing regular maintenance to ensure the system remains functional.

children.name: Disposal
children.description: Properly retiring the system according to industry standards and regulations.

children.description: Creating a holistic view of the organization to ensure alignment between business goals and IT strategies.

children.name: Business Architecture
children.description: Defining the structure and operation of an organization.

children.name: Business Management Systems
children.description: Implementing systems such as ERP, PLM, CRM, and SCM to streamline business operations.

children.name: Data Architecture
children.description: Designing the structure of an organization’s data, ensuring it is well-managed and accessible.

children.name: Data Governance

children.name: IT System Architecture
children.description: Designing the architecture of IT systems to support business processes and goals.

children.name: Project Management
children.description: Planning, executing, and closing projects to achieve specific goals and meet specific success criteria.

children.description: A guide that outlines project management practices and standards.

children.name: Procurement Management

children.description: Creating management systems that adhere to privacy regulations.

children.description: Identifying risks to privacy and implementing countermeasures.

children.description: Understanding principles and methods for designing secure systems.

children.name: Strategic Use of Data and AI
children.description: Strategic use of data and AI involves understanding how to leverage data for business insights and decision-making.

children.name: Data Understanding and Utilization
children.description: This area focuses on comprehending data intricacies and extracting meaningful insights.

children.name: Data Comprehension
children.description: The ability to understand shapes, patterns, and trends in data.

children.name: Data Verification
children.description: Ensuring data accuracy and reliability through methods like statistical validation.

children.description: Creating actionable strategies for implementing data and AI within business contexts.

children.name: Conception and Design
children.description: The ideation phase where data-driven solutions are conceptualized.

children.name: Problem Definition
children.description: Identifying business challenges and defining key performance indicators (KPIs).

children.description: Involves designing approaches, implementing data strategies, and evaluating their impact.

children.description: Developing a structured plan for data acquisition and analysis.

children.name: Analysis Evaluation
children.description: Measuring the effectiveness and accuracy of data analyses.

children.name: Business Implementation
children.description: Actual deployment of data strategies and ensuring their alignment with business goals.

children.name: Mathematics and Statistics
children.description: Foundation of data science, focusing on mathematical concepts and statistical methods.

children.name: Probability
children.description: The study of randomness and uncertainty.

children.name: Descriptive Statistics
children.description: Summarizing and describing features of a data set.

children.name: Inferential Statistics
children.description: Drawing conclusions about populations from sample data.

children.name: Linear Algebra
children.description: The study of vectors, vector spaces, and linear transformations.

children.name: Calculus
children.description: Mathematics of change, focusing on derivatives and integrals.

children.name: Programming Skills
children.description: Essential coding skills for data manipulation and analysis.

children.name: Python
children.description: A versatile programming language widely used in data science.

children.name: R
children.description: A programming language and free software environment for statistical computing.

children.name: SQL
children.description: A domain-specific language used in programming and managing relational databases.

children.name: Data Manipulation and Analysis
children.description: Techniques for preparing and analyzing data.

children.name: Data Cleaning
children.description: The process of identifying and correcting errors in data.

children.name: Data Wrangling
children.description: The process of converting raw data into a usable format.

children.name: Data Visualization
children.description: The graphical representation of information and data.

children.name: Machine Learning
children.description: Algorithms and techniques for predictive modeling and data analysis.

children.name: Supervised Learning
children.description: Learning from labeled data to predict outcomes.

children.name: Unsupervised Learning
children.description: Finding hidden patterns in data without labeled outcomes.

children.name: Model Evaluation and Selection
children.description: Assessing model performance and selecting the best model for deployment.

children.name: Feature Engineering
children.description: The process of selecting, modifying, or creating features for model input.

children.name: Big Data Technologies
children.description: Tools and frameworks for handling and analyzing large data sets.

children.name: Hadoop
children.description: An open-source framework for distributed storage and processing of big data.

children.name: Spark
children.description: A unified analytics engine for big data processing, with built-in modules for streaming, SQL, machine learning, and graph processing.

children.name: NoSQL Databases
children.description: Databases designed to handle large sets of distributed data.

children.name: Data Engineering Basics
children.description: Fundamental concepts and practices in data engineering.

children.name: ETL Processes
children.description: Extract, transform, and load processes for data integration.

children.name: Data Warehousing
children.description: The storage of data in a centralized repository for reporting and analysis.

children.name: Data Pipeline Construction
children.description: Creating a set of processes for moving data from one system to another.

children.name: Specialization Areas
children.description: Advanced areas of expertise within data science.

children.name: Natural Language Processing
children.description: A field of AI that enables computers to understand and interpret human language.

children.name: Computer Vision
children.description: A field of AI that enables computers to interpret and understand visual information from the world.

children.name: Time Series Analysis
children.description: Techniques for analyzing time-ordered data points.

children.description: Working effectively with others to achieve common goals.

children.description: Creating a portfolio to showcase skills and experiences.

children.description: Participating in data science competitions to solve real-world problems.

children.description: Developing individual projects to demonstrate skills and creativity.

children.description: Engaging in open source projects to gain experience and recognition.

children.description: Building a professional network and engaging with the data science community.

children.description: Participating in industry events to learn and connect with others.

children.description: Becoming a member of data science groups to share knowledge and resources.

children.description: Ongoing education and skill enhancement.

children.description: Enrolling in courses to gain new skills and certifications.

children.description: Creating a compelling resume that highlights skills and experiences.

children.description: Practicing interview scenarios to improve performance.

children.name: Computer Science
children.description: The foundational discipline that involves the study of algorithms, data structures, computational theory, and software engineering principles.

children.name: Software Engineering
children.description: Software engineering is the application of engineering principles to software development in a methodical way.

children.name: Optimization
children.description: The process of making something as effective or functional as possible, often involving algorithms and resource management.

children.name: Data Structures
children.description: A way of organizing and storing data to enable efficient access and modification.

children.name: Arrays
children.description: A collection of items stored at contiguous memory locations.

children.name: Trees
children.description: A hierarchical data structure that consists of nodes, with a root node and sub-nodes.

children.name: Algorithms
children.description: A set of instructions for solving a problem or performing a task.

children.name: Computational Theory
children.description: The study of the fundamental capabilities and limitations of computers.

children.name: Team Development
children.description: The practices and methodologies essential for developing effective team dynamics in software projects.

children.name: Git/Git Workflow
children.description: A version control system for tracking changes in source code during software development.

children.name: Team Building
children.description: The process of creating a cohesive and effective team environment.

children.name: Readable Code
children.description: Writing code that is easy to read and understand, which enhances maintainability and collaboration.

children.name: Technical Writing
children.description: The practice of documenting software and technical processes in a clear and concise manner.

children.name: Software Design Methods
children.description: Techniques and principles for designing effective and maintainable software systems.

children.name: Requirements Definition Methods
children.description: Techniques used to gather and define the requirements of a software project.

children.name: Domain-Driven Design
children.description: An approach to software development that focuses on modeling the domain of the application.

children.name: Software Design Principles (SOLID)
children.description: A set of principles aimed at making software designs more understandable, flexible, and maintainable.

children.name: Clean Architecture
children.description: An architectural pattern that separates the software solutions into layers, making them independent from frameworks.

children.name: Design Patterns
children.description: General reusable solutions to common problems in software design.

children.name: Non-functional Requirements Definition
children.description: Specifying criteria that can be used to judge the operation of a system, rather than specific behaviors.

children.name: Software Development Process
children.description: The structured approach to software development that encompasses project management, quality assurance, and development methodologies.

children.name: Software Development Management
children.description: Managing software projects using various methodologies such as Agile and Waterfall.

children.name: TDD (Test-Driven Development)
children.description: A software development approach in which tests are written before the code.

children.name: Software Quality Management
children.description: Processes and activities that ensure the quality of software products.

children.name: OSS License Management
children.description: Understanding and managing licenses for open-source software.

children.name: Web Application Basic Technologies
children.description: Core technologies required for developing web applications.

children.name: HTML/CSS
children.description: HTML is the standard markup language for creating web pages, while CSS is used for styling.

children.name: JavaScript
children.description: A high-level programming language that enables interactive web pages.

children.name: REST
children.description: A set of architectural principles for designing networked applications.

children.name: WebSocket
children.description: A communication protocol that provides full-duplex communication channels over a single TCP connection.

children.name: SPA (Single Page Application)
children.description: A web application that interacts with the user by dynamically rewriting the current page.

children.name: CMS (Content Management System)
children.description: A software application that enables users to create, manage, and modify content on a website without needing specialized technical knowledge.

children.name: Frontend System Development
children.description: The process of developing the user interface and user experience for web applications.

children.name: UI Design
children.description: The process of making interfaces in software or computerized devices with a focus on looks or style.

children.name: Responsive Design
children.description: An approach to web design that makes web pages render well on a variety of devices and window or screen sizes.

children.name: Mockup Development
children.description: Creating visual representations of a product's interface to communicate design ideas.

children.name: Frontend Frameworks
children.description: Frameworks that provide a structure for building client-side applications.

children.name: PWA (Progressive Web Application)
children.description: Web applications that use modern web capabilities to deliver an app-like experience to users.

children.name: Technology Trends
children.description: Emerging technologies that are shaping the future of software engineering.

children.name: Metaverse
children.description: A collective virtual shared space created by the convergence of virtually enhanced physical reality and persistent virtual reality.

children.name: Smart Contracts
children.description: Self-executing contracts with the terms of the agreement directly written into code.

children.name: Digital Currency
children.description: Any currency that is available only in digital form, not in physical form.

children.name: Informatics
children.description: The science of processing data for storage and retrieval.

children.name: Materials Field
children.description: The study and application of materials in engineering and technology.

children.name: Bio Field
children.description: The study of biological data and the application of computer science in biology.

children.name: Measurement Field
children.description: The application of technology in collecting and analyzing measurement data.

children.name: GX (Green Transformation)
children.description: Strategies and technologies focused on reducing environmental impact and achieving sustainability.

children.name: Human Skills
children.description: Human skills refer to the interpersonal skills that enable individuals to communicate, collaborate, and lead effectively.

children.name: Leadership
children.description: Leadership involves guiding and motivating a group towards achieving a common goal.

children.name: Team Building
children.description: The process of assembling a group of individuals into a cohesive unit that works together effectively.

children.name: Communication to Involve Others
children.description: The ability to convey information effectively to engage and inspire team members.

children.name: Diversity and Inclusion (D&I)
children.description: Creating an inclusive environment that values diverse perspectives and backgrounds.

children.name: Empowerment
children.description: Encouraging individuals to take initiative and act with confidence.

children.name: Collaboration
children.description: The ability to work effectively with others towards a common goal.

children.name: Facilitation
children.description: The process of guiding discussions and meetings to ensure productive outcomes.

children.name: Listening
children.description: The skill of actively understanding and interpreting what others are saying.

children.name: Questioning
children.description: The ability to ask questions that stimulate thinking and conversation.

children.name: Structuring Points
children.description: Organizing discussions to clarify and summarize key points.

children.name: Psychological Safety
children.description: Creating an environment where individuals feel safe to express their thoughts and ideas.

children.name: Types of Organizations and Teams
children.description: Understanding different organizational structures and team dynamics.

children.name: Conceptual Skills
children.description: Conceptual skills involve the ability to understand complex ideas and visualize the big picture.

children.name: Goal Setting
children.description: The process of defining objectives and determining a course of action.

children.name: Future Thinking
children.description: The ability to envision potential future scenarios and their implications.

children.name: Storytelling
children.description: The art of using narratives to convey messages and connect with audiences.

children.name: Visionary Leadership
children.description: Leading with a clear and inspiring vision for the future.

children.name: Creative Problem Solving
children.description: The ability to generate innovative solutions to complex challenges.

children.name: Design Thinking
children.description: A user-centered approach to problem-solving that emphasizes empathy and innovation.

children.name: Lateral Thinking
children.description: Approaching problems from new angles to generate creative solutions.

children.name: Hypothesis Thinking
children.description: Formulating and testing hypotheses to explore solutions.

children.name: Fail Fast
children.description: Embracing failure as a learning opportunity to iterate and improve.

children.name: Critical Thinking
children.description: The ability to analyze information and make reasoned judgments.

children.name: Critical Thinking and Logical Thinking
children.description: Evaluating arguments and reasoning to make informed decisions.

children.name: Systems Thinking
children.description: Understanding complex systems and interconnections within them.

children.name: Adaptability
children.description: The ability to adjust to new conditions and challenges effectively.

children.name: Agility
children.description: The capacity to respond quickly to changes and challenges.

children.name: OODA Loop
children.description: A decision-making process that emphasizes observation, orientation, decision, and action.

children.name: Lean Thinking
children.description: A systematic method for waste minimization within a manufacturing system without sacrificing productivity.

children.name: Customer and User Understanding
children.description: Understanding customers and users is critical in design to ensure that the products meet actual needs and preferences.

children.name: Interview Design
children.description: Creating structured interviews to gather qualitative data from users or stakeholders.

children.name: Workshop Design
children.description: Facilitating workshops to encourage collaboration and ideation among stakeholders.

children.name: User Research Techniques
children.description: Methods such as A/B Testing, Card Sorting, Diary Studies, and Focus Groups to gather insights about user preferences.

children.name: A/B Testing
children.description: A method to compare two versions of a webpage or product to determine which performs better.

children.name: Card Sorting
children.description: An activity that helps in understanding how users categorize information.

children.name: Diary Studies
children.description: A qualitative research method where users record their experiences over time.

children.name: Focus Groups
children.description: Moderated discussions with a group of users to gather feedback and opinions.

children.name: Market and Competitor Research
children.description: Analyzing market trends and competitor products, both quantitatively and qualitatively.

children.name: Research Result Analysis
children.description: Analyzing qualitative and quantitative research data to derive actionable insights.

children.name: Participatory Design
children.description: Engaging users in the design process to ensure their needs are met.

children.name: Personas and Journey Maps
children.description: Creating user personas and mapping user journeys to visualize user experiences.

children.name: Value Discovery and Definition
children.description: Identifying and defining the value that the design will deliver to users and stakeholders.

children.name: Frameworks for Value Discovery
children.description: Using tools like Service Blueprint and Assumption Matrix to identify and validate value propositions.

children.name: Ideation Techniques
children.description: Methods such as Brainstorming, KJ Method, Scenario Method, and Paper Prototyping to generate ideas.

children.name: Brainstorming
children.description: A group creativity technique designed to generate a large number of ideas for the solution to a problem.

children.name: KJ Method
children.description: A method for organizing and prioritizing ideas based on affinity.

children.name: Scenario Method
children.description: Creating scenarios to explore how users will interact with a product.

children.name: Paper Prototyping
children.description: Low-fidelity prototyping using paper to visualize and test design ideas.

children.name: Value Proposition
children.description: Defining the unique value that a product or service provides to its users.

children.name: Product and Service Policy Formulation
children.description: Creating concepts and policies that guide product and service development.

children.name: Design
children.description: Creating and developing the visual and functional aspects of products and services.

children.name: Prototyping
children.description: Building prototypes to test and validate design concepts.

children.name: High-Fidelity Prototyping
children.description: Creating detailed and interactive prototypes that closely resemble the final product.

children.name: Low-Fidelity Prototyping
children.description: Creating simple, often hand-drawn, prototypes to visualize concepts.

children.name: Information Architecture
children.description: Structuring information to facilitate usability and findability.

children.name: Content Design
children.description: Designing content that meets user needs and aligns with strategic goals.

children.name: Accessibility and Usability Design
children.description: Ensuring that products are accessible to all users, including those with disabilities.

children.name: UI Design
children.description: Designing user interfaces that are visually appealing and easy to use.

children.name: Wireframing
children.description: Creating wireframes to outline basic page structure and elements.

children.name: Mockups
children.description: Creating detailed visual representations of the final design.

children.name: Object-oriented Design
children.description: Designing user interfaces based on user tasks and goals.

children.name: Design Systems
children.description: Creating a collection of reusable components and guidelines that help maintain consistency across products.

children.name: Components Library
children.description: Creating a library of UI components for easy access and reuse.

children.name: Typography and Color Systems
children.description: Establishing typography and color guidelines to ensure visual consistency.

children.name: Human Behavior Principles and Psychology in Design
children.description: Applying knowledge of human behavior and psychology to enhance user experiences.

children.name: Ethical Check of Finished Products
children.description: Evaluating products for ethical considerations post-design.

children.name: Verification
children.description: Testing and validating design concepts to ensure they meet user needs.

children.name: Concept Testing
children.description: Gathering feedback on design concepts from users to validate ideas.

children.name: Planning and Conducting Usability Evaluations
children.description: Designing and executing usability tests to assess the effectiveness of the design.

children.name: Other Design Technologies
children.description: Exploring additional design technologies and methodologies to enhance design capabilities.

children.name: Branding Policy Formulation
